column11: Review Text

column8: A real alternative to the other parks, but beware: elephant attacks keep happening here
column11: A really scenic park with a number of smaller elephant herds. However, attacks by the grey giants are really commonplace here, especially a cow likes to target the jeeps. With a knowledgeable jeep driver, however, this is harmless. Emphasis is on knowledgeable!!! You are not here for this, as in Minneriya/Eco or Kaudulla surrounded by dozens of other jeeps. But not for children and the faint of heart

A green setting with significant biodiversity. The animals seem peaceful and the presence of many babies proves it. Guard guides are essential to make you discover the park and in permanent connection to allow you to see as many animals as possible.

A beautiful park! So much better than the other parks where there are far too many jeeps and the elephants cannot leave. It took a while but very many elephants can see, special birds and beautiful nature
Accompanied by our guide this 4WD safari allowed us, in respect of animals I find, to contemplate multiple elephants, from afar, up close, which was particularly magical. Few tourists, many locals.
Very beautiful landscape but unfortunately very few animals seen some elephants but very wild more than in other parks

column8: Just need a driver for this Tour.
column11: You don‚Äôt really a tour guide for this booking.  Just a driver if you‚Äôre coming from Kandy.  The view is amazing and not that far.  Get a Tuk Tuk motor cart to reach the top.

column8: Wasgamuwa the land of elephant watching
column11: A good friend of mine called me for a trip to wasgamuwa.. was amazing! I was highly reluctant to go as I never been to wasgamuwa however I wanted to try and see... check the place out... it was a nice place they had booked near the park... we got to see elephants and bears and other animals... this park has no leopards... maybe 1 or 2 not sure didn't see but mainly ppl come for birding and elephants! We had an awesome cook the place we stayed... we got the ingredients and they made the food...  we stayed in a bungalow sort of which was open to the outside ... I highly recommend a portable mosquito net (this is to keep out not only the mosy but other insects that come at night when sleeping) that can be folded and taken on trips you can get them from arpico super store... Also each time before you goto sleep please lift the bed mattresses and check underneath for any insects also get some mosquito repellant as well... :D

column8: One of the best place for Safari.
column11: One of the best places to see elephants but mostly can be seen after about 3.30 pm. we went in August and no other animals except deer at one place. Anyhow, the river bath is sometimes we enjoyed as it is safe and scenery.  We went for a full day trip and the trackers had to clear roads and hardly any elephants in the morning but you can enjoy endless jungle flora.

Amazing Safari if you want a less touristy place to visit! We visited after reading how busy ayala can get. We had a whole jeep to ourselves so was able to swap sides depending on where the  animals were. We only saw one other jeep whilst on our safari so pretty much had the park to ourselves! We saw well over 100 elephants in the wild and a few REALLY close, including baby elephants too. We saw other animals such as water buffalo, deer, crocodile, aguana, peacocks, wild boar and many different birds. We didn't see any leopards but we mainly wanted to see elephants, which we definitely did!! Great half day doing the safari!!
Saw several wild elephants in different groups and places, even had a mock charge from one! Also many peacocks and some deer.
We were there with the family.It was a nice experience for all of us.We saw plenty of elephant at once.Definitely recommend

Wasgamuwa is a national park situated in Matale & Polonnaruwa districts, bordering the Mahaweli River. Wasgamuwa is very popular for drastic and tallest wild elephants and birds. The best time to visit is the evening when elephants become more active and keep clam, less noisy since wild elephant may attack your jeep. Our visit to Wasgamuwa NP is superb. There are 3 wildlife bungalows inside the park and we stayed Wavulabe Wildlife Bungalow which is very nice place in the band of Mahaweli River. Bungalow keeper Sarath was very helpful person and his foods are tasty and superb. Our tracker is Dhanushka, he is very experience tracker. He saved us from unexpected elephant attack. But the Park Warden and the management is not that much great since we have to wait more than one hour to find a tracker and clear the entrance
Its an Elephants paradise. For those who frequest Yala etc this is more laid back and you can see elephants in larger heards. Lots of other bird species etc and a very different park.

One of the best national parks in Sri Lanka to spot wild elephants. Ideal to visit in evenings when elephants are more active. You can park the vehicles at entrance and get a safari Jeep from there. Jeep cost you 3500 rupees in addition to the entrance fees which costed us around 1000 rupees for 5 people. During the safari they stop at the banks of mahaweli river and you could spend some quality time there as well. We had a very successful safari here and spotted many elephants.

We had an amazing experience here, and the flexibility of your own driver means that if a noisy group turns up, you can go the other way (as we did!) Agree with other reviews, less busy than some parks. Elephants in abundance. A few buffalo, monitor lizards and some great birds. Highly recommended

Wasgamuwa National Park is recently established as a wildlife haven, an offset for a major irrigation project in the vicinity.  The accessible parts are mostly regrowth scrub, following years of dispersed grazing and hunting, altho there are also some high quality damp forests on the less accessible lower mountain slopes (also part of the national park). The standard Sri Lankan large animals are all too easily seen, notably elefants, buffalo, spotted deer, crocodiles and others, plus PLENTY of bird life and even a few varieties of snakes.  You may be lucky enough to catch leopards (altho these can never be guaranteed). It's a bit 'off the beaten track', best accessible via Dambulla and the park itself can be accessed by jeep safari (including park guide).  We stayed at the nearby Safari Lodge (a great location - more on that later). It's a great alternative to Yala.  In Wasgamuwa you can see the wildlife in natural habitat without the swarms of tourists that harry the wildlife in better known parks, such as Yala.  Sri Lanka provides some of the best 'big wild animal' experiences outside Africa.

Wanted a park with few crowds and in an area where roads weren‚Äôt congested. Wasgamuwa was perfect. Booked a three hour trip for $60 including park fees and enjoyed  it all. Only two other cars there all afternoon, beautiful scenery and saw lots! Monitor lizards, mongoose, buffalo , spotted deer, and lots of elephants - really close too!
-You can visit by a Safari Jeep. -Drivers are familiar with the timing and locations of the animals.

Spent  3 days in Wasgomuwa. Booked the Wavulabe wild life circuit bungalow.  Booked online cost SLR 12,000 (USD 60)  for 10 adults  for two nights.  Nice drive via Naula and Elahara.  Basic facilities at the Circuit bungalow.  10 Beds with clean linen and solar powered lights. Need to bring the rations . Keep in mind there no fridge . Two cooks and tracker lives in. Can provide basic Sri Lankan cuisine. Lots of Elephants and birds.  Was the  dry season. Saw the Red faced Mal Koha, black eagle and and all the other common birds. Disappointed not to see a sloth bear . Missed seeing a leopard by a whisker . Nice bathing spots in the Mahaweli  river. Wasgomowa  is not as congested a Yala and Wilpattu . Thick jungle  and vast plains.  Highly recommended for all wild life enthusiast . However facilities are basic at the Wild life circuit bungalows. Still I would recommend as it provides easy access for Safaris. Drove back to Colombo via Riverston  Nice drive . But road is under construction but need a 4 wheel drive.

We arrived late as we went over the Knuckles range which was a highlight in itself. The animals were mainly hiding though we saw a lot of elephants, water buffalo, monitors and some rare birds. I saw from a distance what looked like a small cat like animal. The riverbank is a beautiful place to stop and have lunch or dinner. It is not so crowded as other parks and at the time, we were the only ones there

This park has a very high success rate for those wanting to view elephants roaming and feeding in their natural habitat. You may find small families or a large herd. Many companies run safari tours that usually last 3 to 4 hours. The tracks through the park are very rough so be prepared for a bumpy but very enjoyable experience. We were able to view many elephants during our afternoon safari, though unlike Yala National Park we didn't see much other wildlife except for some deer and many different bird species. The park is very dusty so don't wear good or light clothing unless you want to change the colour to a nice shade of dusty brownish red.
Hard to see other animals than elephants, beautiful jungle, If you could stay one night it^s more than enough. Anyway  best place to spend time and release stress.

Staying in Kandy, we wanted a park we could get to in a day and where we were almost certainly going to see elephants. We did a lot of research and eventually chose Wasgamuwa. We were not disappointed. The park was beautiful and full of all sorts of wildlife. We saw many different types of birds and butterflies, as well as wild bore, crocodiles, lizards and monkeys. We were desperate to see elephants, which we did eventually. We were one of only a handful of jeeps in the park that day and the only jeep in the area as we watched a herd of 15-20 elephants slowly emerge from the jungle. It was spectacular. There were a few things we wish we‚Äôd know beforehand, however. 1) Tickets cost $10 US for foreigners. You also have to pay 40RPs for your driver, 250RPs for the jeep and a service charge of $8 US which includes a guide from the park. Our guide really knew his stuff and was very helpful (apart from when he fell asleep for 5 minutes!). 2) As soon as you arrive, a jeep driver will offer you a price for a jeep and try to make you agree instantly. Take your time. There was only 1 jeep when we arrived, but there were more waiting outside, so don‚Äôt feel you need to agree. Another jeep will come and you can say you‚Äôll just wait if a driver is asking too much money. We settled on 6500RPs for 3hrs but ended up giving 7000 because we stayed in the park a lot longer. I think we probably overpaid though. 3) Elephants and other wildlife start to come out after the heat of the day, around 2-3pm, so aim to start your safari around then and not too much before. 4) We weren‚Äôt very impressed with the bathroom facilities or other amenities on arrival. Come prepared with food and drink and stop for the toilet just before you arrive!

Wasgamuwa National Park is located in the districts of Matale and Polonnaruwa and bordered by the `Mahawelil and `Amban' rivers and probably contains more wildlife than others, in terms of diversity. There are many Safaris, camps and holiday bungalows nearby the park. Elephants, deer, reptiles, many species of birds, can be seen in the park. Camping sites situated in the park enable you to observe animals.
i had a nice jeep safari in this park. we sow Elephants, bears,dears and hundreds of birds including peacock and migrate birds

Wasgamuwa National Park most renowned place for birds observation and for its photography. This National Park spanning over 36,900 hectares is bordered by two main rivers named Mahaweli Ganga and River Amban Ganga in east and west. The Ganga means River in Native Sinhalese language. The altitude varies from over 500m at the Sudu kanda hill to just 76m along the Mahaweli Ganga. The combination of a number of small reservoirs and Sudu kanda (White Hill) mountain range affords fine trekking opportunities for keen hikers. Tropical dry mixed evergreen forest predominates, characterized by tall trees. climatic conditions are that of the dry zone. Rain fall is mainly with the northeast monsoon (Maha) in October-February. Inter-monsoon rains occur in March-May. Annual rainfall increases from about 1,750 mm in the north to 2,250 mm in the south. Mean annual temperature is around 27 centigrade. 143 species of birds reported here are endemic Red-faced malkoha and Ceylon jungle fowl are common sight in the park. Among the bird populations are Sri Lanka Trogon, racquet tailed drongo, endemic yellow fronted barbet, endemic Sri Lanka spurfowl, white necked stork and lesser adjutant stork. The center of the attraction is herds of elephants up to 150. The best time to enjoy the sight of large herds is during November to May. The entrance to Wasgamuwa National Park is at Handungamuwa. The park can be conveniently reached from several tourist attractions. From Kandy: Kandy, Hasalaka and Hettipola.Approximately 50km northeast of Kandy.Turn off at Hasalaka on the Kandy-Mahiyangana road and proceed via Wilgamuwa upto Wasgamuwa. Visitors from Matale and Polonnaruwa areas can reach Wasgomuwa via Laggala and Wilgamuwa. The Wilgamuwa Japan Bridge provides the easy access to visitors coming from the Mahaweli system-C. From Dambulla and Polonnaruwa ancient cities, through Bakamuna, Elahera and Laggala ‚Äì Pallegama

Have you tried camping here? If you do you now what I am talking about. Me and my friends went camping in Wasgamuwa National Park. You need to book the lace in advance from the forest department(colombo - battaramulla). It was Rs. 2100 I think. We took the bus from fort at 12 midnight and went to Mahiyanganaya. Once we went there there is a bus that goes close to the jungle. Get down on the last stop and hire a jeep. there are plenty of jeeps to hire around. Make sure you pick the right ones coz they will be with the vehicle all the night with a guide. There is a campsite call "Thunmang handiya" which is close to the Mahaweli river. Camp there and the view is breath taking. Take a look at the pics. Also when we hire the jeep we are entitled to go for a safari as well. We saw a lot of elephants and birds. then out of no where a leopard cross the road as well. The night time in the jungle was amazing. We heard so many animal's sounds and enjoyed the sound of the river that flow next to our tents. The jeep was parked and ready in case of emergencies. The guid and the driver stayed at the jeep and they didn't bother our privacy. Make sure you take enough food for those two as well. When ever we want and feel we jump in to the water and the water level is not even up to your hip. water is clean. We didn't drink, but we use for the cleaning. Take drinking water. Also there is a toilet if you are not an outdoor person. In the morning we saw elephants crossing the river. It was amazing with the morning sunrise. Overall its a great experience and I hope you guys will like to try. One more thing don't pollute anything around. Be responsible and take all the garbage with you. Also when cleaning try to minimize soap and other chemicals as there are fish in the river. The sand in the river is a good soap to clean your plates.

We visited Minnereriya National Park yesterday and found it good, but congested and only saw elephants. In comparison, we were one of 3 safari jeeps at Wasgamuwa, and we saw the other jeeps briefly. We saw over 15 different species of animal, ranging from deer, water buffalo to crocodiles, monkeys and wild boars. Catching the 5:30am safari was well worthwhile as we got to witness the sun rising over the stunning landscape. We also had a tracker, as well as a driver, which made sure we saw as many animals as possible. The backdrop of the Knuckles mountain range created a breath taking backdrop that neither of us will ever forget.

We decided to choose this Safari as it didn‚Äôt seem as busy as other parks in Sri Lanka, and actually, we did not see many jeeps during our evening safari which was great. Regarding wildlife, it was ok, we saw a group of elephants in a lake (but a bit far distance from our jeep), wild buffalos, deers, and many types of birds. What we did not like about the safari was the following. The guide was in the back of the jeep with us and each time he spotted some animal, he needed to hit the jeep to let the driver know to stop which was messy and animals got scared and run away. Not sure if this is the standard procedure (hopefully not and we just were not lucky with our driver). Also the duration of the safari was only 90 minutes when I think it usually takes at least 2 hours, but it must be a problem of our travel agency.
Go early to see the things other wise the animals will disappear in to the jungle .Tigers,Elephants,Deers,Bulls,Peacocks are Mainly be seen. The camping site near the mahaweli river is a great place
Going on Safari was unique and wonderful.  We so enjoyed the elephants.  Lots of pictures were taken and also the elephants were numerous and available to see up close.

We went there End of April and discovered lots of animals and almost no other visitors. We toured two hours without seeing other Jeeps. Wildlife was numerous from ibis, cormorant and junglefowl, wild buffalo, deers, elefants, warans, wild boars, peacocks, etc. Pleasant that the park wasn't crowded and we could enjoy it to the fullest.

I told them that I would love to relax with them in some idyllic hotel anywhere in Sri Lanka. This gentleman walked up to me and said as you know we are very widely travelled, what is the point of going to any lovely hotel anywhere on earth as 90% of the time only the geographical location changes most hotels and the food they serve are almost the same. I then said can we keep this short, what would you say is the best place to 'chill out' (in modern terms :-). Hence Wasgamwa National Park. The Park Area is protected from hunters naturally. You can experience mainly couple of dozen wild elephants in 'Parades' if that is the appropriate term, crocodiles, wild deer, wild bo, bears and numerous other forms of wild life. A far more energizing holiday than staying in any hotel world wide.

we went there in last month and it is raining there.not crowded as Yala, Minneriya and Udawalawa. there are few safari jeeps outside the park and we got a good driver.entrance tickets are not too expensive and one of there guide come with us to describe the things and he is very pleasant. but unfortunately we were not lucky to see even one elephant but we saw a lot of peacocks and deer and other animals.

We were promised elephants and water buffalo and we got both in abundance as well as a host of avian subjects. The park was clearly a popular destination but the 4x4 drivers are great at getting you sited for the best shots possible. The marsh elephants were out in force and we counted over 130 in one herd. The drivers spent time and used their expertise to position us for maximum exposure. All in all a great afternoon!

Wasgamuwa is a quite place. You can see lot of wild elephants at its best. we saw elephants, deers, mongoose, wild pigs and more. small park but can see variety of animals. Not like Yala or Wilpapttu still not been destroyed by men.

It was a life time experience. Fortunate enough to see the gang of 15 elephants ( with baby elephants) who were roaming around the jungle. Our safari jeep drove very close to this elephant gang and none of the wild elephants didnt care about us. It was a such wonderful moment with lot of joy and also the fear of getting attacked by the wild elephants. Saw nearly 20 odd wild elephants during the tour. The best time to go the safari is around 3.00 p.m. This will give you a great a chance to see lot of wild elephants because they travel to drink water to river. Make sure to go over to Mahaweli River to enjoy the beautiful nature and have a cool swim at the river. Wild Life department officers take a good care of keeping the environment clean. Please dont take any plastics or shopping bags to the river. Its a great gift from mother nature to have such a wonderful wild park.

If you want to watch wild elephants in their natural habitat, wasgamuwa  national park is one of the best in Sri Lanka. We went on a safari jeep about four rounds and saw elephants each time. But be warnd, its not for the weak hearted as few times elephants chased after us and scared us to death.but it was an awesome and thrilling experience nevertheless.

I would say, the wildest and the biggest elephants live here. Due to access and distance, other locations are more popular. The elephants are know as "vil ali" aka Marsh Elephants, because they have fodder & water throughout the year.

This is the third biggest national Park in Sri Lanka. Good surface area with animals such as: Elephants, deers, and plenty of birds. The park organizes two main safaris one between 6-9 am and the other between 3-6 pm, so make sure you are there around those times, otherwise you will be lingering around for a while and not much to do on foot really. You will have to pay park entrance of about 2500 rupee, and also pay to rent a jeep (we paid 4000 rupee to rent a jeep for 3 hours. Add to these costs tips for driver and tracker/ guide. There is no cafeteria and so I suggest you bring your own food and drinks with you, as the closest store is in about 2-3 kms. What you will see on the safari in terms of fauna is not impressive ( Nothing compared to what you would see in a Safari in Africa). Nevertheless, it is relaxing and very enjoyable. You will actually get to see a couple of cool birds. Apparently they have bungalows should one decide to stay overnight, but I didn't get the impression the park was well equipped, so you do that at your own risk! Guide was very friendly and helpful but sadly below average English, and that did restrict the amount of information we could gather about the park's natural flora and fauna. Overall, if you want a relaxing safari and do not have very high expectations as to how many animals you will see and how close you can get to them, it is a good place to go.

Wasgamuwa NP located in Polonnaruwa &  Matale districts.You can access from DambullaÔºåBakamunaÔºå Hettipola & Handungamuwa or Kandy ÔºåMathaleÔºåRaththota,Laggala ,Hettipola & Hsndungamuwa.Kandy Mathale road is more scenic because you have to travel via reverston.It's nearly 250km from Colombo and takes 5-6 hrs.Best season for visit is Sep to MarchÔºå beacuse it's rainy season.You can see Sri Lankan elephantÔºåSamber deerÔºåspotted deerÔºå barking deerÔºåjackal ,Sri lankan leopard Ôºå sloth bear and some mammals also lots of birds too.Basically leopard & sloth bear sightings are rare but if you have luck you can see them.Wasgamuwa is popular for elephants and you have to visit between oct to feb for see large bunber of themÔºå beacuse it's rainy season unless elephants are migrating for Minneriya & Kawudulla erea.If you are lucky you can see larger heards like 70-80 elephants but in some days you can't see even one üòû.There are 3 bungalows in side the park & Mahaweli & wawulebe are located near Mawali riverÔºå those two bungalows are powered by solar panelsÔºå But Kaduru pitiya bungalow has 3 face current.so the bungalow equipped with fans & fridge also.Rates for half day safari is 4000-4500 & fullday 7000-8000.The park is not crowded like Yala not even WipattuÔºåso you can enjoy calm safari.Have fun.. Cheers!

I saw a lot different kinds of beautiful birds, mongoose, deer, crocodiles end elephants :) 2 adult males; a jonger male and 2 smaller herds (not in dry season). The national park has much less touriststhan other national park. This is a good thing because you really feel like your in nature and not in a crowded safari. There is also a small muzeum at the entrance of the national park with some antlerts and skuls. If your Lucky you can see some rare Sri Lankan sloth bears there.

Visited this park in Feb 2016. This park is on the outskirts of strict touristic area and unfortunately roads are nit so good thus not many tourists reach to this park. So it was our jeep apart from another french friend of ours from Lyon. We saw many different animals including Crocodiles, Buffalos and many elephants in groups. You could also site lot of colourful birds. All in all it was a tiry but worthwhile drive to the park.

We camped inside the national park and i must say the experience was fantastic! We spotted so many birds and i managed to click some amazing shots! The elephants were an absolute pleasure to observe! The park wasnt crowded with crazy safari jeeps and we felt like we had the whole place to our selves.
This wild animal sanctuary is NOT a zoo, and that is what makes the experience a trip of a lifetime.You can see many Sri Lankan animals & endemic birds in Sri Lanka.You can see the big elephants too.
Approximately 40Km northeast from Kandy.The park proberbly contain more wildlife than others , has more diversity

Great elephants. I got to wash one with a coconut husk. Don't use the toilets though. Its wonderful to see the elephants in their natural habitat. You get to feed an elephant with a big milk bottle too.
Nice place one of the best places, sooo relax and quiet, very less crude and more elephant and birds can see.
On a good day...you will see many elephants, on a bad day....nothing.....take your food....if the river is calm....have a bath....protect your food from monkeys.....

Great place to see wild life :)  If you are lucky enough you might be able to see 50-60 elephants in one place. Definitely this would be ideal place to go safari as well. Not only wild elephants you can see many other wild animals as well.

I visited after the rain on a week day everything was green and beautiful only about three vehicles inside the park was very lucky to see elephants,deer,crocodile ,many birds and many peacock dance,i have always enjoyed my visits to Wasgamuwa since it's not very crowded a park you must visit

We can't recommend this more highly - far far better than a visit to the (distressing) elephant orphanage near Kandy. On a three-hour safari we saw somewhere between 50 and 100 wild elephants in family groups, roaming free - yet the safari jeep drivers managed to get us up close to some of them, as long as we were quite quiet. We also saw a range of other wildlife, including monitor lizards and water monitors, crocodiles, water buffalo, giant squirrels, Brahminy Kites, Fish Eagles, torque monkeys, grey langar monkeys, chameleons, a huge grey fish owl, Asian open bills, pelicans, red coots, green bee-eaters, and many more creatures besides. The guide/safari driver was knowledgable and friendly, and was happy to tailor the tour to what we wanted to do (if you want to stay looking at elephants all the time, that's fine; if you want to move on and see other animals/birds, the guides are happy to accommodate). If you can, take some binoculars, though, as you'll see much more.

I will not rate this place above Wilpattu or Yala National parks. However, if you are interested in watching massive WilAliya then you should visit this place. Tips: 1. One day afternoon /evening is good enough for this trip 2. Morning is useless 3. Don't expect to see sloth bear or leopard here 4. If you are staying inside, make sure you have all those things you need including extra batteries and power banks. You will get only lights, not power outlets for charging (it is from solar power DC current) 5. If you want to bath in Mahaweli river , be careful there are massive Crocodiles !!!!! We saw them only after 2 hours play in the river....!!

We visited Wasgamuwa park for an afternoon safari, starting at 2pm.  We had a guide from the park in the Jeep with us who explained to us about the different animals and plants.  It was extremely informative.  We saw many birds, peacocks, butterflies, water buffalo and many elephants, we saw a herd of female elephants with their young and a few solitary male elephants.  A fantastic trip.  Entrance to the park is about ¬£10 per person, our home stay organised our safari Jeep which was ¬£17.50.  A fantastic trip for us and worth every penny.  This park is less frequented by tourists, we had a car & driver to take us, I'm not sure what the public transport would be like to get here. I imagine it would be limited.

You can see elephants in hundreds in their natural behavior, at close proximity. Apart from those , except for fer herds of deer, there were no many animals, perhaps bad luck. Various types of cranes were there.
only a few elephants. just dust roads and almost no other wild life. Could be the season, I am not certain.

This is the place to see Elephants in the wild where they belong. You can join a 4x4 trip with a guide and drive through the park to the irrigation reservoir or tank as the local's call them. We saw Elephants bathing and feeding on the grass, ripping it up and then knocking it against their feet with their trunk to remove the soil from the roots before eating it. There were young elephant barely able to stand. We also saw deer and jackals and a great variety of bird life from eagles soaring to waders feeding. A highlight of our visit to Sri Lanka and a place we would love to return to. WE gather you can camp there which would be special.

Visited Wasgamuwa National Park as a part of our Knuckles trek. We arrived in Knuckles around lunch time & visited the park for the evening safari. There were lots of wild elephants roaming around in herds giving us good photo opportunities. Some of them even gave a go at us once we lingered too much amidst the. There was a "Loner" called "Bonnet" who was very popular since the elephant used to attack jeep bonnets. Fortunately it didn't attack ours. If you're an elephant lover this is a very good place to visit. However if you want a diversified safari, then I think this is not your cup of tea. We witnessed many spotted deer, wild boar & monkeys as well.
The trip was very interesting saw many herds of wild elephants, spotted deer and,jackals many peacocks and peafowls ,storks, serpent eagles, bee eaters
Few hours of safari yeilded a handful of birds, one deer and one squirrel. Possibly due to the floods - maybe better at other times.

My friend and I arrived at Polonnaruwa via the train to realise, there really wasnt much to the place (in terms of sight seeing) besides the national park and the ancient city. Upon desperation from boredom, we decided, despite the really high prices, to join the safari. Ok, so you have to pay for the Jeep, the entrance fee etc. For 2 people, its a little over US 100. For that, you get to see, some elephants kicking and eating grass, some birds and ALOT of other Jeeps. It's fascinating to see your first elephants, but after that, its just more elephants, and more elephants. It's hard to enjoy them with the sounds of other Jeeps and exhaust. Altogether, I left feeling a tad unsatisfied. I am glad i saw them, but I wasn't sure if the price justified it.

Visited Wasgamuwa National Park on 23rd and 24th Dec. Probably the easiest to get there from Colombo is through Kurunagala, Dambulla, Bakamuna, Hettipola. The road is not as pictures as the road from Matale through Riverstone and then to Hettipola but probably quicker to reach the destination. You should book the bungalows through Wild Life (-----) to stay in the Park as that is the best way as you could get out early to the forest to see animals. Even you could go camping as it is facilitated through Wild Life. Two out of the three bungalows as well as the camping site is closer to Mahaweli river. There are accommodation outside the Park as well and you could easily get a safari jeep. The roads in the Park are not that bad and you can use a jeep with two wheel drive. You could see animals closer to the nature than some of the other Parks as Wasgamuwa is not that crowded by visitors probably due to the distance from Colombo. It was great to see many numbers of elephants roaming around and checking you and your vehicle out to see whether you are a friend or an enemy!!  There are leopards, bears, deer‚Äôs, different types of birds and other animals. Visit, enjoy, don‚Äôt leave anything!!
